conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the induced current and power in the two scenarios where the metal rod slides at different speeds.
The induced EMF (\(\mathcal{E}\)) in the loop due to the motion of the rod can be calculated using Faraday's law of induction: \(\mathcal{E} = B \cdot l \cdot v\).
When the rod moves at speed \(v_1\), the induced EMF is \(\mathcal{E}_1 = B \cdot l \cdot v_1\).
When the rod moves at speed \(v_2\), the induced EMF is \(\mathcal{E}_2 = B \cdot l \cdot v_2\).
The current \(I\) in the loop can be found using Ohm's law: \(I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R}\).
The current when the rod moves at speed \(v_1\) is \(I_1 = \frac{B \cdot l \cdot v_1}{R}\).
The current when the rod moves at speed \(v_2\) is \(I_2 = \frac{B \cdot l \cdot v_2}{R}\).
The ratio of the loop currents is \(\frac{I_1}{I_2} = \frac{1}{2}\).
The power \(P\) delivered by the external force to maintain the constant velocity of the rod is given by: \(P = F \cdot v\).
The force \(F\) required to move the rod is equal to the magnetic force on the rod, which is given by: \(F = I \cdot B \cdot l\).
So, the power can be written as: \(P = I \cdot B \cdot l \cdot v\).
